column4: 1810.–A number of leading characters among the Canadians
column5: who were Members of the House of Assembly (twice dissolved for improper conduct) and the proprietor of a French paper
column7: have been arrested and thrown into jail
column8: upon a charge of treasonable and seditious practises ; the printing press
column10: &c. also taken possession of. This vigorous measure of Sir James Craig
column11: has astonished the Canadians not a little
column12: but the consequences will be no doubt beneficial to the country
column13: as it has crushed a faction which has for some years been gaining strength
column14: and acquiring dangerous influence over the minds of the inhabitants
column18: in the extreme ; therefore easily misled by demagogues among their countrymen
column19: who seize every opportunity of stirring up all those prejudices which the people of this country naturally have against the British : for
column20: having been allowed to preserve their language
column21: they are nearly as much Frenchmen now as they were at the conquest. Quebec

column25: under a warrant from the Executive Council
column26: on a charge of treasonable practises. On Monday evening
column28: and last evening Mr T. Taschereau
column30: and committed by the same authority on the same charges. The Commander in Chief in Scotland gave an elegant dinner
column32: on the 4th curt. to celebrate the King's birthday-day–at which several of the Nobility and Gentry
column35: were present. Among the other accidents that occurred on the King's birth-day
column36: from the imprudent use of gunpowder
column37: is the death of girl in Richmond Street.– Her clothes were set fire by a squib
column39: although immediately taken to the Infirmary
column41: that she died before morning. A very melancholy accident happened at a place called the Pease
column42: Berwickshire. As one of the baggage carts of the Forfarshire militia was stopping there
column43: a fine boy about eight years of age
column46: and was climbing on the wheel
column49: and the wheel passing over his body
column50: crushed him to death. The unfortunate mother was upon the cart when this unhappy accident happened. On Thursday night
column53: was broken into and about five pounds in silver
column57: and a pocket-book containing some bills and papers carried ; some partial payments are marked on the bills. The villains appear to have entered the shop by forcing up the window shutter with an iron bar
column58: and then breaking a pane of glass
column59: by which they got the iron bolts and the window opened. On Saturday last

column63: and killed him instantly. A few days ago

column1: ID379Trewman's Exeter Flying PostExeterEnglandUnited Kingdom18100111informCORONER'S INQUEST.–An inquest was held yesterday evening
column6: on the body of Ann Paris
column9: not more than 17 years of age
column12: had been reduced by some unknown melancholy circumstance
column13: to the most forlorn and destitute situations. It was stated in evidence
column14: that she had taken her lodgings only seven weeks
column15: and that during that time she had evinced the most wretched state of mind
column18: urged on by the poignancy of her feelings
column20: she swallowed a considerable quantity of laudanum. On the violence of her death-pangs coming on
column22: but too late to be of any assistance
column23: and in a short time she expired.–The Coroner's Jury returned a verdict of Lunacy. The history of this poor young creature is at once romantic and interesting. She is the daughter of a Monsieur Paris
column24: who was well known in the commencement of the Revolution
column25: and in which he suffered. Madame Paris
column27: took refuge in this country; and in the ruin of her fortune
column28: became a governess in a noble family in Scotland. After this she had a house in the New-road; and
column30: died of the rupture of a blood vessel. Her daughter had been placed at an eminent boarding-school near one of the new squares; and on the death of her mother was placed under the guardianship of a Member of Parliament
column32: with the most liberal and benevolent attention to her destitute situation
column33: resolved to complete her education; and she had every master of eminence in all the elegant arts. She spoke French and Italian; touched the piano with great execution; sung with taste; and had read beyond her years. About six or eight months ago she was met in the square
column34: when walking with the other young ladies
column35: by a young man in the dress of a midshipman
column36: who followed her to the door
column37: and who wrote to her under the name of Jones. A correspondence took place. Her imagination was fired; and she eloped with him under a promise of marriage. His address was found in her box
column38: and they were traced by her guardian
column39: and separated. Jones declared that she was virtuous
column41: and as a proof of it he was ready to marry her with her guardian's consent. In effect they were married and she was completely undone. In about a fortnight or three weeks Jones threw off his disguise
column42: and fairly told her his real character– that he was no sailor
column43: but lived by his shifts; that he had married her only for the sum her protector had paid him
column44: and that she must provide for herself. She was abandoned; and the shock had such an effect on her imagination
column45: that she has ever since shewed signs of a disordered intellect. With a heart that shrunk from vice
column46: she was flung on the world without a friend or a home; and in this deplorable state she became the victim of necessity. About three weeks ago
column48: who is distinguished for his gallantries
column49: and who by his address and attentions so won upon her affections
column50: that she could neither speak nor think of any other object. This fatal attachment absorbed her whole soul. They entered into engagements to live and die only for one another; and in the frenzy of this passion
column51: or under the idea that she could not be his
column53: she took the desperate resolution of dying for him. She had prepared three phials of opium
column55: and she died with a spirit of heroism; for no persuasion nor force could make her
column56: when seized with the nausea of the poison
column57: take any antidote to the draughts. She would not suffer the medical men to approach her–and though after stupefaction came on
column59: they all failed of effect. crime;obituary
